analyzeResult.content:
New Industry Enters Era of Increased Public Scrutiny
When Judge John J. Sirica decided in May to stop proposed scientific experiments that would have re- leased genetically engineered organ- isms into the environment, he unleashed a new element of uncer- tainty for many companies work- ing on recombinant DNA products with agricultural applications.
At first, the immediate implica- tions for business of the court's in- junction seemed limited, since it ap- plied only to experiments that used federal funding. And the original suit, filed by environmental activist Jeremy Rifkin, that would require environmental impact statements and from which the injunction de- rived, has yet to be decided. But a subsequent motion filed by Rifkin at the end of July would, if granted. broaden the application of the suit to many if not most commercial field tests
How or whether these actions will hamper the activities of private en- terprises in the long run awaits fur- ther court decisions. What seems surer at this point is that the array of firms loosely called the biotech- nology industry has passed another milepost on its march toward com- mercialization.
The impact of Rifkin's legal ma- neuvers, of his debates with bio- technology industry executives on network television, of Congressio- nal hearings held by Rep. Albert Gore Jr. (D .. Tenn.) a year ago on the environmental implications of genetic engineering. and of a spate of articles in the general press in recent months has been to fix the issue of biotechnology's risks in the public eve. Analysts already had termed 1984 the "year of transition"
Biotechnology firms labor to minimize impediments to development while retaining public's trust in safety of recombinant DNA products
David Webber, CSEN New York
for biotechnology-the year in which the first significant products would move to market. Now it ap- pears that 1984 will mark another transition: the passing of the indus- try into an era of intense public scrutiny, with the unpredictability that implies.
In January, an Office of Technolo- gy Assessment report on commer- cial biotechnology ranked public perception as the least important of 10 factors-ranging from financing to regulation to intellectual proper- ty laws-affecting the commerciali- zation of biotechnology. But the analysis pointed out that how the populace views the held could in- fluence commercialization more in the U.S. than elsewhere. In addition. the report citeu surveys showing public apprehension about applied genetics and ignorance of genetics in generel.
"At the current time, public per-
ception is not an important factor in the commercialization of biotech- nology," the report states. "How- ever. the volatility of a potential public response must be noted. Were there to be an accident due to com- mercial biotechnology, the public's reaction could be extremely impor- tant to the future of biotechnology."
For the industry-both the small. entrepreneurial firms that have spearheaded the technology and the large, diversified firms that are investing heavily in it now-the growth of public worry about the safety of genetic engineering is not entirely unexpected. Critics of ge- netic engineering are worried be- cause everything they consider risky, from industrial-scale manu- facturing to the release of modified organisms to genetic therapy in hu- man beings. is close to reality. At stake for the companies involved are the billions of dollars already invested in the promise of the technology's success. While critics are crying. "Slow down!" the advent of marketplace competition in ge- netic engineering has driven home to the companies the fundamental necessity of speed and timing.
In what promises to be a far more strident atmosphere than in the past. the industry is attempting to work out an approach by which it can retain the public's confidence in the promise and safety of genetic engi- neering without sacrificing the initiative, ability to plan, and free- dom to exploit opportunity that are part of its requirements for busi- ness success. Almost every repre-

paragraphs.content: New Industry Enters Era of Increased Public Scrutiny

When Judge John J. Sirica decided in May to stop proposed scientific experiments that would have re- leased genetically engineered organ- isms into the environment, he unleashed a new element of uncer- tainty for many companies work- ing on recombinant DNA products with agricultural applications.

At first, the immediate implica- tions for business of the court's in- junction seemed limited, since it ap- plied only to experiments that used federal funding. And the original suit, filed by environmental activist Jeremy Rifkin, that would require environmental impact statements and from which the injunction de- rived, has yet to be decided. But a subsequent motion filed by Rifkin at the end of July would, if granted. broaden the application of the suit to many if not most commercial field tests

How or whether these actions will hamper the activities of private en- terprises in the long run awaits fur- ther court decisions. What seems surer at this point is that the array of firms loosely called the biotech- nology industry has passed another milepost on its march toward com- mercialization.

The impact of Rifkin's legal ma- neuvers, of his debates with bio- technology industry executives on network television, of Congressio- nal hearings held by Rep. Albert Gore Jr. (D .. Tenn.) a year ago on the environmental implications of genetic engineering. and of a spate of articles in the general press in recent months has been to fix the issue of biotechnology's risks in the public eve. Analysts already had termed 1984 the "year of transition"
Biotechnology firms labor to minimize impediments to development while retaining public's trust in safety of recombinant DNA products

for biotechnology-the year in which the first significant products would move to market. Now it ap- pears that 1984 will mark another transition: the passing of the indus- try into an era of intense public scrutiny, with the unpredictability that implies.

In January, an Office of Technolo- gy Assessment report on commer- cial biotechnology ranked public perception as the least important of 10 factors-ranging from financing to regulation to intellectual proper- ty laws-affecting the commerciali- zation of biotechnology. But the analysis pointed out that how the populace views the held could in- fluence commercialization more in the U.S. than elsewhere. In addition. the report citeu surveys showing public apprehension about applied genetics and ignorance of genetics in generel.

ception is not an important factor in the commercialization of biotech- nology," the report states. "How- ever. the volatility of a potential public response must be noted. Were there to be an accident due to com- mercial biotechnology, the public's reaction could be extremely impor- tant to the future of biotechnology."

For the industry-both the small. entrepreneurial firms that have spearheaded the technology and the large, diversified firms that are investing heavily in it now-the growth of public worry about the safety of genetic engineering is not entirely unexpected. Critics of ge- netic engineering are worried be- cause everything they consider risky, from industrial-scale manu- facturing to the release of modified organisms to genetic therapy in hu- man beings. is close to reality. At stake for the companies involved are the billions of dollars already invested in the promise of the technology's success. While critics are crying.
